bug.short_desc: [WorkbenchParts] EditorHistoryItem.saveState does not work for uninstalled bundles

long_desc.thetext:
Copied from bug 154748:
If I try to close editor before uninstalling the bundle, following exception occur on trying to exit workbench:
org.eclipse.core.runtime.InvalidRegistryObjectException: Invalid registry object at org.eclipse.core.internal.registry.TemporaryObjectManager.getObject(TemporaryObjectManager.java:98) at org.eclipse.core.internal.registry.ConfigurationElementHandle.getConfigurationElement(ConfigurationElementHandle.java:26) at org.eclipse.core.internal.registry.ConfigurationElementHandle.getAttribute(ConfigurationElementHandle.java:34) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.registry.EditorDescriptor.getId(EditorDescriptor.java:260) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.EditorHistoryItem.saveState(EditorHistoryItem.java:225) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.EditorHistory.saveState(EditorHistory.java:152) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.saveState(Workbench.java:1953)
The reason: IEditorPart instance passed into EditorManager.removeExtension() in this case has no IEditorInput (null returned from editor.getEditorInput() call) as a result, corresponding IEditorInput will not be removed from EditorHistory on attempt to uninstall bundle with Editor and Workbench fails on saving the state.
Shouldn't we remove EditorHistoryItem from EditorHistory on closing corresponding editor to get rid of these problems?
Maybe we can do something with the ordering. PW

bug.short_desc: NoClassDefFoundError

long_desc.thetext:
I install tptp.runtime-TPTP-4.2.0.2.zip and emf-sdo-xsd-SDK-2.2.0.zip in my Eclipse SDK 3.2 (JDK 1.5) and Eclipse Modeling Framework (EMF and XSD) SDK 2.2.0
I can run my application with normal Eclipse Run lancher. However, when I try to profile my application with TPTP, I got the following error:
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: brokercore/BrokerCore Exception in thread "main"
The VM arguments I use for both Run and Profile configurations are same. It is:
-Djava.class.path="main:lib/jess.jar:lib/openjms-0.7.5.jar:lib/j2ee.jar:lib/mysql-connector.jar:lib/exolabcore-0.3.5.jar:lib/pg73jdbc3.jar" -Djava.security.policy=etc/java.policy -Djava.rmi.server.codebase="file:/c:/eclipse/workspace/padres/build/padres-0.2.jar file:/c:/eclipse/workspace/padres/build/lib/openjms-0.7.5.jar file:/c:/eclipse/workspace/padres/build/lib/j2ee.jar" -Dpadres.build="c:/eclipse/workspace/padres/build"
I have the space inside the "-Djava.rmi.server.codebase". I saw some previous bug reports have the same problem as mine. And this bug has been fixed. And I have already installed the latest version from TPTP website. I am just wondering why I still have this problem? Is it because I include other unrecognized charactors in my VM arguments?
Would you please attach the workspace/.metadata/.log file for further analysis?

I run my application with normal Run launcher and Profile launcher seperately this morning. And I get the following information:
------------------------------------------------------------------------
!ENTRY org.eclipse.hyades.trace.ui 2006-08-23 10:34:51.844 !MESSAGE Processed: 66011 bytes, bytes/second: 33005, events processed: 639, events/second: 319, elapsed time: 2 seconds
!ENTRY org.eclipse.hyades.trace.ui 2006-08-23 10:36:00.079 !MESSAGE Processed: 66011 bytes, bytes/second: 33005, events processed: 639, events/second: 319, elapsed time: 2 seconds !SESSION 2006-08-23 10:36:55.188 ----------------------------------------------- eclipse.buildId=M20060629-1905 java.version=1.5.0_06 java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US Command-line arguments: -os win32 -ws win32 -arch x86
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.resources 2 1 2006-08-23 10:37:21.126 !MESSAGE Skipping builder net.genady.rmi.RMIBuilder for project padres. Either the builder is missing from the install, or it belongs to a project nature that is missing or disabled.
!ENTRY org.eclipse.hyades.trace.ui 2006-08-23 10:45:01.204 !MESSAGE Processed: 66011 bytes, bytes/second: 33005, events processed: 639, events/second: 319, elapsed time: 2 seconds
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any suggestions about this? Thanks
It looks like RMIBuilder is missing. But I am sure that the function works well when I run it from the normal Run launcher.
Would you please compare the classpath entries between Run and Profile mode and see if there any difference?

I compared them, and they are the same. Actually, I did not change it at all. It is the default entries, including Bootstrap Entries (JRE System Library[jdk1.5.0_06]) and User Entries (all .jar file in the lib directory of my project).

This may relate to bug 106568.
Can you try adding '-XrunpiAgent' in VM arg in RUN mode, and launch in RUN mode, then create a profile ATTACH-JAVA PROCESS launch congiuration, select the agent you created via -XrunpiAgent and continue profile?

I can profile my application right now by following your suggestion. Thanks very much. I have one more concern that whether I can only profile after my application has been started or not? Did I miss smth for the profiling setting? Thanks for your help again.

By setting '-XrunpiAgent:server=controlled' (default is server=enabled), you can block the application from running until the profiling agent is attached and monitored.
For detail please read : http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/installguide/agentcontroller_42/win_ia32/getting_started.html#Invocation_of_the_Java_Profiler_from_the_Command_Line
We need to further analysis why the VM args are not passed corrrectly in profiling mode.

close bug as fixed.
VM args should be passed correctly in profile launch configuration by now in the latest TPTP release.

bug.short_desc: implement generic serialization for query hits

long_desc.thetext: Move BugzillaTaskExternalizer.readQueryHit() to DelegatingTaskExternalizer to provide generic serialization of classes that extend AbstractQueryHit.

Turns out this is not as straightforward as I thought. Currently repositoryUrl and taskId maintained separately for query hits but serialized as a combined taskHandle. I think the data model of AbstractQueryHit should match that of AbstractRepositoryTask and store a taskHandle instead. AbstractRepositoryTask.getTaskId(taskHandle)/getRepositoryUrl(taskHandle) can be used to access the respective url and id.
Thoughts?

Created an attachment (id=48430) remove code duplication

bug.short_desc: ${build_project}/build.xml does not list targets for an external builder

long_desc.thetext: When I create an external ant builder for a project and I specify the build file using ${build_project} in the path, no targets are listed on the targets tab. If I change to use ${project_loc} it works, or ${workspace_loc:/build.xml} also works.
${build_project} is a variable that is set to the project currently being built during the actual build. I do not see how would we resolve its value at "compile" time?
I agree that the current behavior is consistent, but the UI knows which project definition is being modified, so why can't it define build_project properly?
I would propose that is the difference between project_loc and build_project

I agree that is the difference.
I just see that if you define an external tool builder using project_loc, automatic builds for projects will be run with a project_loc definition for the currently selected project instead of the one being built.
A simple workaround is to first define the build.xml path using project_loc, select the targets and then redefine it to be build_project. Is that an agreeable workaround? Would users know to do this? And if so, why can't the UI just do it?
No plans for changes.

When you launch a search in the Help with "Associating Editors with file types" for instance, you cannot find it, you will find the section External editors with at the end of it in Related Tasks, a link to "Associating Editors with file types", if you click on the link, then the message unavailable topic appear because it still links to tasks-51.htm instead of tasks-51.xhtml.

The same applies for the Greek build (0822)
thx Peppy

*Files in the tasks section that are .xhtml: tasks51, tasks53 and tasks57. *Files in the getting started section that are .xhtml: qs-02d, qs-24a, qs-34a, qs-34b, qs-34c.
Links to all of these files could be broken. I wonder why our tools that check links and such didn't catch these?
I checked the rest of the doc and there are no more xhtml files.

Created an attachment (id=48466) Patch to org.eclipse.platform.doc.user against HEAD
I agree it's strange that our link checking didn't pick this up.

>I wonder why our tools that check links and such didn't catch these? The tool I used to check for broken links only checks the doc i.e. it starts at the root of the webserver. If there are help files that cannot be reached via this root then such files aren't checked and might contain broken links.
Fix released.
Shouldn't the fix be backported to 3.2.1 as well?
I discussed with Karice and we decided this isn't critical for 3.2.x.

Not fixed in 0828 build. M.
This bug will be deferred, is it possible to have a defect number to track it? Thanks a lot,
There are no plans to fix this bug in the 3.2.1 stream. However, it is fixed in the 3.3 stream (see Target Milestone field).

The help system has relaxed the requirement to use *.xhtml extension for XHTML files needed for the dynamically filtered help content. We did it precisely for this reason - we realized that the breakage in links pointing at the renamed documents was not acceptible.
Curtis, can you comment - what is the recommendation for file names now?

My recommendation is to use the extension that reflects the contents of the file whenever possible. That is, for HTML use .html, for XHTML use .xhtml. Makes sense, after all, you probably shouldn't write a PDF file with a .doc filename.
If not possible, for whetever reason, specifying XHTML in an .htm/.html file will still work fine.

bug.short_desc: [misc] Support marker undo

long_desc.thetext: Now that undo for marker operations is implemented from the UI views such as task list and bookmark view, we should also add undo support when performing operations from the text ruler.

Created an attachment (id=48425) org.eclipse.ui.editors.patch
This patch changes the AddMarkerAction and MarkerRulerAction to use the new API for undoable marker operations. Note that this API is currently experimental and may evolve in 3.3. However, it would be nice to get these changes in so that we can start promoting the use of marker operation undo.

Note: A separate issue not addressed in these patches is whether the undo history for an editor should show the marker operations performed in the editor's ruler. ie, if you delete a task or bookmark from the ruler, should you see "Undo Delete Task" in the undo menu for the editor? Currently you will only see it in the Package Explorer and Task List.
Note that showing these operations in the undo history for the editor would take additional code. Currently the document undo manager responds only to changes in the document. To accomplish this, we would have to add code in the text editor classes that watch for operation history changes to the workspace and add the editor's undo context to those that affect the editor's underlying input. I can provide patches that do this, but did not pursue until I know whether this is a desirable feature from a platform text point of view.
See bug #7691 (particularly comments 13 & 14) for explanation of the new feature.

bug.short_desc: Generic annotation editing solution

long_desc.thetext:
Since being introduced for general use in Java 5, annotations have become an increasingly prominent mechanism for specifying metadata that has a relationship with Java code. Many technologies, including several Java EE technologies (for example EJB 3), now make use of annotations to allow configuration of related metadata.
Given the level of complexity in defining this metadata in certain circumstances, tool providers such as the WTP-JPA project are interested in providing a way for end users to configure annotations via a UI. Currently this is done with a custom view, as there is no generic annotation editing facility provided by Eclipse. Others have created their own annotation editing views for the same purpose.
Since annotations are directly tied to the java source, adopters are limited in their ability to provide UI in a consistent fashion. This is due to the current lack of ability to enhance the Java Editor or its Properties in an Eclipse friendly way.
I am not certain what the best solution is to this general issue. It has been suggested that having the Java Editor activate the Tabbed Properties would allow different extenders to contribute tabs for configuring their annotations on a given type. This solution offers consistency, extensibility, and provides the ability to configure annotations using rich UI if desired. Another possibility would be to have a specific Annotation Properties View, which could be extended by multiple clients to provide context-based values for their particular annotations.

Some questions: - the extent of 'annotations': Is that only about the Java annotations in the source code ('@A(...) void foo()') or also about (custom) annotation information in meta files? - in JDT UI, we like to be editor centric. So we prefer putting the tooling possible to where you type: Code completion, quick fixes, documentation hovers ect. If adding a property view for templates is a suggestion, what can such a view do better?

(In reply to comment #1) > - the extent of 'annotations': Is that only about the Java annotations in the > source code ('@A(...) void foo()') or also about (custom) annotation > information in meta files?
AFAIK the focus is on Java annotations.
> - in JDT UI, we like to be editor centric. So we prefer putting the tooling > possible to where you type: Code completion, quick fixes, documentation hovers > ect. If adding a property view for templates is a suggestion, what can such a > view do better?
It adds another (very likely domain specific) view to a Java element. The advantage I see over an editor centric approach is that one would not have to remember what annotations to use to achieve a certain goal (i.e., abstraction) and all the possible details about an annotation (i.e., simplification).
I guess that everything could be implemented using the editor centric approach. However, allowing a different view on a Java element/annotation would definitely open the usability to folks that prefer adding/removing annotations by selecting or deselecting a check-box or selecting annotation values from a drop down or by clicking on a button that opens a more sophisticated dialog or even a wizard which may require expensive actions, such as database connectivity.
I would probably one of those guys that continue to hit "Ctrl+Space". But I have to admit that I also enjoy the possibility of saving a few keystrokes by using a nice Forms UI like view. ;)

I see the benefit for domain specific annotations. I think to use the properties view for this makes sense. But this is very hard to drive from JDT.UI without a practical use cases. Can for example WTP-JPA take the lead here and let us know what exactly they need so that for example the properties view plays nicely together with the editor?

An update - we have been prototyping the Tabbed Properties solution in order to determine what problems there might be in making this work with the Java Editor. So far we have discovered one issue that would need to be addressed in the Tabbed Properties View before this solution would work. Bug 156277 has been opened to address this.
We will continue to investigate.
Can I move this bug to you, Neil?

I think we are ready to submit a patch that demonstrates what we need from the JDT UI. We were hoping to get the associated bug addressed, but this hasn't happened as of yet, so we can just go ahead and submit a patch for the issue discussed here so that you guys understand what it is we need (which is not much).
So, you can assign it to me if you want, but I plan to assign it back within the next day. :)

>This is due to the current lack of ability to enhance the Java Editor or its >Properties in an Eclipse friendly way. What Java Editor Properties are you referring? Note that there are ways to extend the Java editing and the editor. We open it up piece by piece. It would be good to know what you are looking for in detail.

Created an attachment (id=50902) Basic patch that implements Tabbed Properties in the JavaEditor
I have attached a basic patch that demonstrates what we need from the JDT UI. All this patch does is provide the necessary extension point for supporting the Tabbed Properties in the Java Editor. As a side effect of adding this support, the JavaOutline also support tabbed properties. I implemented the Advanced tab as suggested by the tabbed properties framework to show the old properties table.
There are 2 bugs logged against the Tabbed Properties framework which will affect the use in the java editor and extensions that want to add new properties:
Bug 156277 will allow the JavaEditor to fully utilize the tabbed properties. Currently, the JavaEditor does not implement any properties in the Properties view. If this bug was fixed, the JavaEditor could implement the basic properties just like they are implemented in the Java Outline. This bug being fixed will also allow extenders to deal with the TextSelections from the JavaEditor to add context specific tab properties.
Bug 158607 will also need to be fixed to allow extenders to appropriately extend the java editor tabbed properties without overriding them or other extenders that add tabs.

!!! This patch will break source compatibility of clients due to bug 148844 and hence JDT Text will not commit it unless bug 148844 has been fixed. If bug 148844 won't fixed then the inheritance based extension via ITabbedPropertySheetPageContributor has to be replace by an adapter i.e. via JavaEditor.getAdapter(...).
>As a side effect of adding this support, >the JavaOutline also support tabbed properties. Yes, but in a strange way: after the patch the file's properties appear in an 'Advanced' tab which is wrong. I would expect to see something like that: - 'Resource' tab with the file's resource properties - 'Java' or 'Java Element' with the Java element properties
'Advanced' is a poor name in my opinion.
Karen, can you attach a workspace patch next time? Thanks. Also, note that due to bug 158945 you should currently not put a blank after the ',' when specifying the bundle version in the MANIFEST.MF.

Note regarding source compatibility: 1) this can be broken in rare must-do situations but must be clearly documented in the migration guide. Nothing I'd like to do for this change. 2) the problem is not just for those that reference JavaEditor but also for those that reference any subclass JavaEditor

Created an attachment (id=51002) tabbed properties support in the JavaEditor
I've attached a new patch that incorporates Daniel's suggestions. I renamed the 'Advanced' tab to 'Java'. The patch is a workspace-level patch on the 20060918-1200 integration build.
I don't think there should be a 'Resource' tab in the properties for the Java Outline. Currently, when you select a Class you get resource information about the .java file, you get this information even if you select a Class in the file other than the top-level type. I think you should only get this information by selecting the .java file or the .class file from the package explorer. Regardless, this isn't directly related to this bug, and the JDT UI can approach their implmentation of the tabbed properties as they see fit. My main goal was to not break existing functionality and to support adding new properties in my plugin.

After more investigation, this bug is not dependent on 158607, it would just be nice if it was implemented. It is still dependent on 156277 and I am going to post another patch that directly depends on the patch I've posted for 156277

Created an attachment (id=51771) Patch to implement StructuredSelectionProvider and tabbed properties in the JavaEditor
This patch is dependent on the patch given in bug 156277. I believe I have fixed the problem related to bug number 148844 with this patch, am I wrong about that?

-1 for that patch: - I don't want to an inner class in the Java editor that isn't used there at all - the name IStructuredSelectionProvider is wrong since it is not a selection provider (at least not as it is commonly used within Eclipse) but rather a simple selection converter. Also note, that there is already SelectionConverter.getStructuredSelection(...) which you could probably use.
I removed bug 148844 as blocker since the latest patch resolved this.

Created an attachment (id=52128) implementation of tabbed properties SelectionConverter for the JavaEditor
This is a new patch based on the provided feedback. I was unable to use org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.actions.SelectionConverter because this provides different StructuredSelections that are meant for code assist. This is not what you would want to display in the Properties view.
Forgot to mention that I also updated the patch in bug 156277 that this patch depends on.

Karen,
it seems that your selection converter has lots of code that could be removed if you used helpers like SelectionConverter.getElementAtOffset(...)
Also getting the active page is easier: JavaPlugin.getActivePage()
Another problem is the for loop: I guess you do this to check that the selection only covers one element, right? If so, simply check the elements range against the selection.
HTH Dani

(In reply to comment #18) > Another problem is the for loop: I guess you do this to check that the > selection only covers one element, right? If so, simply check the elements > range against the selection.
I am not sure of the functionality one would want in this situation. If you had a text selection that starts in the IType and the end of the selection is still in the IType what properties would you show? What about the fact that there are IFields and IMethods included in your selection? Should this be considered a multi-selection as it would be in the Outline? Or would you just show the properties for the IType?

I didn't yet think of what should be shown there but only commented on what and how the patch does things ;-)
Up to now JDT Text never converts a text selection into a multi-element selection. We normally have to ways to deal with text selections: 1) we only take the caret location and compute the enclosing element 2) if length == 0 we extend to the word at the given offset then we take the selection and check whether it *contains* an identifier and try to resolve that to a Java element. (see also bug 75353)
I would implement 2) because we do the same for the Declarations and Javadoc view ==> if I select a Java element inside a method then the Properties view would give me information about that element. Not sure whether that fits/helps your model.

Two things I previously missed to mention: 1) the patch is not yet complete: it only handles ICompilationUnit but must also handle IClassFile
2) if there is any change that a properties computation can take a while (e.g. because it needs the AST) then you must do the same as we do in the Javadoc and Declarations view: the information must be computed in a separate job (or thread). Failing to do so will force us to disable the feature again since we cannot accept degradation in typing speed. This however is not part of this patch but has to be considered in the tabbed Properties view architecture. NOTE: it is not good enough to say that clients must ensure the performance. As an example take the Java hover extension point: clients can contribute hovers and we ensure that they are called in the background.

Created an attachment (id=52319) Updated patch
I've updated the patch taking into account your suggestions including supporting displaying properties for class files.

Created an attachment (id=52582) Improved patch
This patch improves the previous one by removing code duplication adding null-checks where needed.

Just saw that bug 12352 is marked as blocking bug and hence noticed that the current solution is a no-go regarding performance because when a user does a selection (e.g. Shift + mouse drag) it continuously notifies the selection converter (assuming the Properties view is open) and also updates the view. While this might be acceptable for views it is not for the Java editor and I strongly suggest to also change this for all other use cases. The trick here is to listen for post selection changed and not for selection changed events. This has to go into the (tabbed) Properties view code. This should probably be put into a separate bug which can then replace bug 12352 as blocking bug.
Performance could be further improved by not updating the Properties view while - in a stacked pane but not in front - hidden as fast view but that's another issue.

bug.short_desc: [Undo] [IDE] - Marker operations become invalid if the marker is deleted and then restored

long_desc.thetext:
Consider this sequence of operations - Create a task - Modify the task's attributes (via properties dialog or cell editor in tasks view) - Delete the task
You may now "Undo Delete Task"
This correctly recreates the marker with all the attributes it had prior to deletion.
Problem/Feature In theory, you should then be able to undo the prior modification of the marker's resources. The current implementation does not support this, since the marker was deleted and recreated. The new marker has a different id. The original update operation knows the original marker and doesn't attempt to establish any relationship based on equality (ie, same location, resource, and attributes). Doing so would be somewhat dangerous since we don't know that all "equal-looking" markers really refer to the original marker.
There are other similar scenarios, but the basic issue is that if a marker is deleted (by a delete, or an undo of a create, etc.) then any other operations that refer to that marker will now be invalid.

This may not be a priority for 3.3, but marking 3.3 for now so that all limitations of the new workspace undo support can be examined and documented. I think we can look at this bug again after we implement undo for resource create/update/delete, because we will have similar issues for resources, not just markers.

I doubt this is a big deal for 3.3.
It didn't turn out to be an issue with resources, since you can always get and keep a handle for a non-existent resource, and it will "work" once the resource does exist. So the handles kept by undoable resource operations tend to work across resource delete/recreates.
But marker id's don't work this way, so the marker ops tend to get stale faster.
I don't see this as a 3.3 issue. Marking REMIND for now.

bug.short_desc: Wrong debug attributes

long_desc.thetext: This is a consequence of sharing the same subroutine code generation for the two returns statements. After the subroutine has been called, the return position is wrong.

bug.short_desc: [breakpoints] Undo support for creating, modifying, deleting breakpoints

long_desc.thetext:
I've just released code (see bug #7691) that provides API classes for operations that create, update, or delete markers. These classes are contained in the package org.eclipse.ui.ide.undo. The classes allow you to describe a marker you wish to create, delete, or update. Executing the operation will perform the marker operation, as well as handling errors such as CoreExceptions, adding the operation to the undo history, and handling undo/redo if requested.
The bookmark and tasks views now use these classes to implement undo of task and bookmark create/delete/update. Similar techniques should be possible to undo the creation, deletion, and modification of breakpoints.
At a minimum it would be pretty simple to provide such an undo history from the breakpoints view. A more complicated question is whether the text editor itself should make the undo history for breakpoints available as part of the history. (See bug #154779).
I can help with this feature in the way of patches, or more detailed explanation, but will wait for the debug component to assign a priority to it. I'm interested in this because we want to flesh out the API's for the marker operation classes and I think debug using it may help expose holes or assumptions in the code.
Not planned for 3.3
*** Bug 205488 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Investigate use of new Bugzilla web service support

long_desc.thetext:
It looks like the web service interface to Bugzilla will make it into the next release.
224577: Bugzilla could use a web services interface https://bugzilla.mozilla.org//show_bug.cgi?id=224577
The sooner we start testing against this new api the sooner we'll know what it lacks and can submit new bug reports to get those missing features added.

Just a heads-up, bugzilla 2.23.4[1] has been released. This is the last snapshot before the 3.0-RC1 release, which has an ETA of 2 weeks from yesterday (2007-02-06)[2].
[1] http://www.bugzilla.org/news/ [2] http://wiki.mozilla.org/Bugzilla:Meetings:2007-02-06
Thanks Ismael. I hope to revisit this soon to test the new rpc interface. Do you have any pointers to documentation for this new interface?
Unfortunately I don't. I am just a user of Bugzilla (and Mylar).

So, bugzilla 3.0-RC1 has been released. The release notes have some pointers to documentation of the webservice interface:
http://www.bugzilla.org/docs/3.0/html/api/Bugzilla/WebService.html http://www.bugzilla.org/docs/3.0/html/api/Bugzilla/WebService/Bug.html http://www.bugzilla.org/docs/3.0/html/api/Bugzilla/WebService/Bugzilla.html http://www.bugzilla.org/docs/3.0/html/api/Bugzilla/WebService/Product.html http://www.bugzilla.org/docs/3.0/html/api/Bugzilla/WebService/User.html
Not related to this bug, but I tried using this version with Mylar 1.0.1 and 2.0M1 with this version of bugzilla.
Mylar 1.0.1 works fine for most activities except when changing a bug. In that case, Mylar fails to recognise the successful message and shows a dialog box with the page (as if an error had ocurred).
Mylar 2.0M1 seems to work fine for everything, but it tends to close and re-open the task editor instead of re-using it.
Are there any plans to support bugzilla 3.0-RC1 in the 1.x series or is that a 2.0 feature only?

Great thanks for investigating this Ismael. Generally speaking we won't be merging new functionality back to the 1.x stream unless we have a compelling reason to do so. There are no plans to support Bugzilla 3.0 in 1.x. Is there a reason you cannot move to the 2.0 stream?

I think that's a fair decision and I assumed that it would be the case, but wanted to confirm it.
I have been using the 2.0 stream for my open-source contributions, but at work we use quite a few plugins and forcing everyone in the team to migrate to the eclipse 3.3 milestone builds (required by the 2.0 stream) isn't feasible as you can imagine. It's no big deal to wait a bit longer before we can migrate to Bugzilla 3.0, Eclipse 3.3 and Mylar 2.0 though. :)

bug.short_desc: Give user initiated synchronization priority over background synchronizations

long_desc.thetext: If a large scheduled background sync is underway and the user opens a task, the synch will get scheduled along with the others which can cause a delay. The user initated sync should get priority over the background synchronizations.

I agree that there should be a higher priority for user initiated sync's, especially when they are triggered from the editors refresh button. A user could push this button and potentially wait a very long time before the editor is refreshed if the refresh job is being blocked by a longer sync job
*** Bug 191738 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
From bug#191738: the big problem is when the task submission is blocked by a big synchronization.

Ability to cancel synchronization has improved but there are some outstanding issues to be addressed in wrt blocking when multiple tasks synchronizing. That said the Bugzilla Connector now retrieves task data much faster so this shouldn't be as much of a problem. Deferring additional improvements to 3.0.
Steffen: this is somewhat related to your upcoming cancellation efforts.

bug.short_desc: faces-config navigation rules editor makes an invalid assumption that the pages are jsp files

long_desc.thetext:
When using the 'Page' tool from the palette to create a navigation rule, the file picker filters the files with a set of 4 known file extensions (jsp, jsv, jtpl, jspx). Our JSF files use a propietary format with a different file extension so we are unable to select them from the dialog. ( see CreateNodeCommand.selectJSPPage() )
NOTE: drag/drop of files to the navigation canvas doesn't make the same assumption and allows the user to drop any file type to create a navigation rule. That is our current workaround.
Also a similar check is made when double clicking on a page. The OpenEditorCommand makes a call to WebrootUtil.isValidWebFile(resource) and if it returns false it shows an error message instead of opening the editor. We have currently have no workaround for this.
Possible fixes: 1. Add some mechanism to declare additional file extensions (or contentTypes) that are valid 'web files'. (from extension point and a preference page). 2. Remove the 'web file' file extension checks completely. 3. Other?

Hi Jean,
Please review this bug and give your feedback. -Raghu

JSP file has four standard extensions: *.jsp, *.jspx, *.jsw, *.jsv. If you want to add another file extension, you need to configure the application server and web.xml file (create a <jsp-property-group> and add <url-pattern> tag for each extension).
I think it is better for WTP (not JSF) to provide an extension mechanism for user to define JSP file extension, so that user can use that extension point to define their own JSP file extension.
A quick fix will be this: 1. User can still drag and drop any type of files from navigator to the navigation canvas, so we will not change to restriction of selecting a JSP file from the dialog; 2. For double click to open the page, we will not check the file extension, but will use default editor to open the file. That makes sense because any type of file can use its own default editor to open it.

Very good suggestion! Thank you! I made a small change to your code, using getFileSpecs(IContentType.FILE_EXTENSION_SPEC) to get JSP file extensions.
So creating a page from palette also works. Hope it solves all the problem.
Related files: WebrootUtil.java in facesconfig.common plugin CreateNodeCommand.java in facesconfig.ui plugin
Codes are checked in the Eclipse CVS.
Closing as part of mass query to clean up old resolved bugs in untargetted milestones.

(In reply to comment #4)
After upgrading to eclipse 3.3/WTP 2.0, I'm reviewing what was fixed for this bug and I think the solution is still flawed.
You are still assuming that the JSF view files are some flavor of JSP. In our case we use a proprietary XML format for defining the JSF component tree that is not related to JSP at all. The JSF spec does not say that the views have to be JSP, so I don't think the Navigation editor should apply that restriction.
While I can add our file extension to the set of JSP Content Types, that introduces additional side effects that I am not really comfortable with. (For example, the JSP Editor becomes associated with our file extension).
I think the same issue would apply for people using facelets for their views. A facelet developer may use a .xhtml file extension (or any other arbitrary file extension) for the views. In the current Navigation editor, the file picker does not let them select non-JSP files.

The JSP component would be happy to help in the content type determination, but there's a limitation with content type describers not having awareness of resources and paths when asked to describe a stream. I opened bug 183309 to deal with encoding support, but you might want to glom onto it more.

Joe, could you take a look at this one. Not sure about this usage pattern, and what component to redirect to. Leaving it with the generic test execution component for now.

I believe this exception indicates that you are sending execution fragments without specifying a valid parentID. If you want the events to appear at the root of the execution history, you must specify the special ID "ROOT", and otherwise, you must specify the ID of an event that has previously been model loaded.
Please consult the schema for the XML fragments for more information. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=42824
I am closing this an invalid, but please feel free to contact me directly if the above doesn't make sense.

The Test Execution Events Schema is also available at:
http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/ >> TPTP Platform >> Technical documentation

bug.short_desc: eclipse automatable close when running

long_desc.thetext:
# # An unexpected error has been detected by HotSpot Virtual Machine: # # Internal Error (4E4D4554484F440E4350500525), pid=1716, tid=1748 # # Java VM: Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (1.5.0_07-b03 mixed mode, sharing)

bug.short_desc: RTE: comma in html filename of an href causes bad link

long_desc.thetext: In the RTE, when a URL contains an href that points to a file whose extension is "html" and the filename contains a comma, it is changed to a MethodElementLink (ie, a guid="xyz" attribute is added). This causes the link to be a broken link when it's published.

Created an attachment (id=48434) patch for fix
when scanning href's, if a possible guid is found, verify that the guid exists in the library first.
please resolve it after the patch is applied.
Patch applied
patch applied
fixed, verified on epf-composer-1.0-M5-N20060829-1815-win32
verified, closed.

bug.short_desc: Workspace crash in M4 using RTE

long_desc.thetext: From time to time M4 crashes when using the RTE in maximized mode, pasting, and navigating with the cursor keys. See attached log file
Created an attachment (id=48435) log file
it happens when pressing <CRTL>--><Right Arrow>
Created an attachment (id=48437) jre crash log

I have a library that I can reproduce it with now. All one has to do is open this library, open a work product, select a text field that already has text in it and press the right arrow key. I attached the log created by the VM for the crash.
See Bug 149441 - not sure if they are duplicates, but they seem to be
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 157340 ***
closed as it's a duplicate.

bug.short_desc: Make decorator for new tasks different from updated tasks

long_desc.thetext: Currently in query results new tasks are no differnt from the changed ones. Please add special decoration for newly created tasks.
This is related to bug 161734 and other issues related to the lack of parallelism between tasks and hits.
Fixed for 2.0.

bug.short_desc: [Wizards] Wizard controls not disabled after 'Next'

long_desc.thetext:
- Create a new Java project from existing source - Select Next - Before the next page shows up, change the contents selection to "Create new project in workspace". This is only possible for projects that take a while to load up. - When the next page shows up, the Finish button is not active
In order to fix this, you need to go Back and try again.
---- My suggestion would be to disable the Contents radio buttons after Next is clicked.
Can you describe exactly how you did the first step 'Create a new Java project from existing source'?

(In reply to comment #1) > Can you describe exactly how you did the first step 'Create a new Java project > from existing source'? >
File -> New -> Project... -> Select Java Project

I could reproduce: - New > Java > Project ... - Java Project - On the first page select 'Create project from existing source' and enter a location that has lots of files (for example 'C:\temp') - Press 'Next' - Progress monitor is shown, but it is still possible to change the radio to 'Create new project in workspace' - Page switches but has 'Next' disabled.
The wizard dialog should prevent that controls can be changed after next has been pressed. Moving to platform.ui.

I think I figured out what is happening. It's easier to see with a stack trace: ControlEnableState.readStateForAndDisable(Control) line: 138 ControlEnableState.<init>(Control, List) line: 94 ControlEnableState.<init>(Control) line: 76 ControlEnableState.disable(Control) line: 106 WizardDialog.saveUIState(boolean) line: 909 WizardDialog.aboutToStart(boolean) line: 309 WizardDialog.run(boolean, boolean, IRunnableWithProgress) line: 847 JavaProjectWizardSecondPage.changeToNewProject() line: 145 JavaProjectWizardSecondPage.setVisible(boolean) line: 114 WizardDialog.updateForPage(IWizardPage) line: 1059 WizardDialog.access$2(WizardDialog, IWizardPage) line: 1041 WizardDialog$4.run() line: 1031 BusyIndicator.showWhile(Display, Runnable) line: 67 WizardDialog.showPage(IWizardPage) line: 1029 WizardDialog.nextPressed() line: 760 WizardDialog.buttonPressed(int) line: 351
When the WizardDialog#nextPressed method is called, showPage() is called for the second page of the wizard. updateForPage() is eventually called from showPage() which calls setVisible() on the JavaProjectWizardSecondPage which eventually calls WizardDialog#run. This results in the widgets on the second page being disabled. However, the first page is still visible - see bug 92422 as to why.
Switching the order in which the pages are set visible doesn't work as a solution because if you set the first page to not be visible first, you will see a blank page when the runnable for the second page is running in its setVisible() method. Assuming that JavaProjectWizardSecondPage#changeToNewProject (which calls WizardDialog#run) cannot be delayed until later, the safest solution is to set the controls on the first page to be disabled before calling setVisible(true) on the second page.
released fix to HEAD for build > 20060905
the (bad) fix for this caused much more serious bug 157044 so I rolled the fix for this out.
found a safer solution that doesn't break the Next/Back button function. released to HEAD for build > 20060913.
The fix in WizardDialog rev. 1.52 looks a bit too complicated to me. I think the 'Map state' is not really necessary; a simple 'ControlEnableState state' would do the job as well, wouldn't it?
Yes, you are right. released update to HEAD for build > 20060914.
have to re-open due to bug 157044

Unless you find a good solution, the insights from bug 157044 comment 9 and following should be added as a big caveat to the javadoc of ControlEnableState (i.e. "it is dangerous to use ControlEnableState if code relies on the enabled state of controls inside the target control").

bug.short_desc: altText does not display in pdf correctly

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Insert a image from BIRT resource folder, remove it from BIRT resource folder. Then edit its altText message in the onRender method, it does not work in pdf output.
Steps to reproduce: 1.New a report and insert a image from BIRT resource folder. 2.Click the image and switch to the "Script" tab, select onRender method, and edit with: this.altText="altText"; 3.Preview in PDF, the altText does not display.

The altText is only show if the image is not exits. see http://www.htmlcodetutorial.com/images/_AREA_ALT.html.
Please verify if the alt text is in action.
iText doesn't support the ALT text.
PDF reader does not support alt-text

bug.short_desc: @model kind="class" fails when used with @model for the constructor

long_desc.thetext: Using @model kind="class" fails when annotating the class constructor with @model. This causes the genmodel wizard to end up with an empty list with no warnings. If there are many annonated packages with many classes in them, this bug can be created with even one of the class constructors being annotated.
Ed Merks has provided a patch for this: http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.tools.emf/msg18727.html
Created an attachment (id=48436) Patched class.
The fix is committed to CVS.

bug.short_desc: [Help] Eclipse requires a symbolic link when issuing the startup command, if eclipse directory is read-only

long_desc.thetext:
We deploy the Eclipse package on Linux as a daemon. We install the Eclipse Help System as root, because we shell script to issue the chkconfig command and copy the shell script to /etc/init.d. All the files (Help System and content) are owned by user/group bin. When starting Eclipse using the start command.
su -s /bin/sh bin -c '/opt/ibm/db2ic/V9/doc/bin/../jre/bin/javaw -classpath /opt/ibm/db2ic/V9/doc/bin/../eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.help.base_3.1.0/helpbase.jar org.eclipse.help.standalone.Infocenter -command start -os linux -eclipsehome /opt/ibm/db2ic/V9/doc/bin/../eclipse -nl en -locales ar bg cs da de el en es fi fr hr hu it ja ko nl no pl pt pt_BR ro ru sk sl sv tr zh_CN zh_TW -noexec -port 51000 &'
which results in the following error:
!SESSION 2006-08-03 14:48:35.598 ----------------------------------------------- eclipse.buildId=M20050929-0840 java.fullversion=J2RE 1.4.2 IBM build cxia32142-20050929 (SR3) (JIT enabled: jit c) BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86, WS=motif, NL=en Framework arguments: -application org.eclipse.help.base.infocenterApplication - locales ar bg cs da de el en es fi fr hr hu it ja ko nl no pl pt pt_BR ro ru sk sl sv tr zh_CN zh_TW Command-line arguments: -application org.eclipse.help.base.infocenterApplicatio n -data /opt/ibm/db2ic/V9/doc/bin/../eclipse/workspace -os linux -locales ar bg cs da de el en es fi fr hr hu it ja ko nl no pl pt pt_BR ro ru sk sl sv tr zh_CN zh_TW
!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi 2006-08-03 14:48:35.867 !MESSAGE Error reading configuration: /bin/.eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.os gi/.manager/.fileTableLock (No such file or directory) !STACK 0 java.io.FileNotFoundException: /bin/.eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/.man ager/.fileTableLock (No such file or directory) at java.io.FileOutputStream.openAppend(Native Method) at java.io.FileOutputStream.<init>(FileOutputStream.java:199) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.Locker_JavaNio.lock(Locker_ JavaNio.java:34) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.FileManager.lock(FileManager.java:36 1) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.FileManager.open(FileManager.java:65 8) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseAdaptor.initFileManager(Eclip seAdaptor.java:818) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseAdaptor.initialize(EclipseAda ptor.java:139) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.Framework.initialize(Framework.java:128) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.Framework.<init>(Framework.java:106) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.OSGi.createFramework(OSGi.java:90) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.OSGi.<init>(OSGi.java:31) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.startup(EclipseStarter.java:272) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:159) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:85) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:58) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:391) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:334) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:278) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:973) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:948)
After further investigation, we found that the eclipse directory is read-only on our server and there is a code in eclipse saying:
In LocationManager.computeDefaultConfigurationLocation() // 1) We store the config state relative to the 'eclipse' directory if possible // 2) If this directory is read-only // we store the state in <user.home>/.eclipse/<application-id>_<version> where <user.home> // is unique for each local user, and <application-id> is the one // defined in .eclipseproduct marker file. If .eclipseproduct does not // exist, use "eclipse" as the application-id.
I think this design is really not good. Since on Linux/Unix platform, eclipse directory is read-only does not mean that the eclipse/configuration and eclipse/workspace directories are read-only.

bug.short_desc: feature request: how far up the stack between stops?

long_desc.thetext:
When I stop at a breakpoint, then run again until I hit the next breakpoint, I'm often deep within the same stack, and only the bottom few frames have changed. But there's no way to tell whether, in the interim, execution went all the way back up the stack and all the way back down, or whether I only popped a few frames back.
So what I'd love to have is some indication, in the VM stack view, that shows me "how far up" I went in between the breakpoints. Sort of like how the variables view will red-highlight things that change across an execution - it would be great if the stack frames that got popped showed up in red.
I don't know whether the VM has that kind of instrumentation built in or not - it's just a feature request :-)

The VM does not provide this information explicitly, but it would be possible to have the JDT debugger infer which frames have changed since the last suspend.
Currently marking as later - i.e. not planned for 3.3
